No story was as compelling as Jin’s, in my opinion, in a long time, and I have been gaming my entire life.Upon purchasing DLC (Director’s Cut) for Iki Island for my PlayStation 5, I kept checking to see when the game was downloaded, as I was eager to play and find out so much more about Jin’s story and his past. Finally, after what felt like forever (it wasn’t that long), I got to sit down and explore Iki Island. I played the story first, finished it in 3 hours and my God… I thought the initial story had me in my feelings, but the Iki Island story and tales had me cry more than once. It was so emotional, so captivating and just felt like I could feel everything as if I were Jin himself. I didn’t want to put my controller down not once. After completing the story I have explored Ikishima, still exploring to find other things I have yet to come across and complete other tales so I can indulge and dive more into Jin’s life and the overall story, and just overall, the scenic beauty is breathtaking and astronomically out of this world.The adaptive triggers and haptic feedback are so much fun and make the game so much more personal. It’s not everyone’s favorite, but to each their own. I also love how the new duels and just battles throughout the island challenge me more than they did on Tsushima overall, especially when weapons are switched on you. It’s definitely improved my dueling skills and makes the game more fun, in addiction to the DualSense added features. The swords clashing, the way gallops from Sora (or whatever you name your horse) vary in feeling whether on rock or on land… Ghost of Tsushima’s Director’s Cut does not disappoint. I was weary at first of the price tag, but not opposed, as I loved the game so I was willing to throw down whatever for the extra content. I’m so glad I did.Amazing job, Suckerpunch Productions. Definitely looking forward to a sequel!

Ghost Of Tsushima Directors cut brings more of what we love about Ghost Of Tsushima , we learn more about clan Sakai dark past whilst fighting a unique threat from the mongol leader “The Eagle” Frame rates are more stable on PS5 version, haptic feedback greatly improves the immersion through the clang of weapons parrying to the purring of cats at the sanctuaries. Adaptive triggers also implemented mainly when using the bow but also the grapple hook. Gameplay is improved with more advanced AI, who will change weapons mid combat requiring you to adjust your approach to face the enemy. As well as shamans who will buff the enemy making a lethal play through even more costly if you mistime your attack or defence during combat. More gear is unlockable through armour, charms etc bringing new ways to play the game. Grapple hook also enhanced to help traverse around camps more easily to plan the perfect ambush. Horse mechanic also upgrades so that your loyal companion can join in the fight taking down crowds of mongols in no time. As well as saddle bags which you can store materials on to replenish any of Jin’s missing gear the next time he jumps on.

Could of used fleshing out a bit more but some pretty strong emotional beats along the way that are noteworthy. The DLC — is worth the money. If you love GoT then IKI Island is a no brainer. After spending more than 1000 hours GOT PS4 I was excited to play the PS5 version. My only complain is that it seems there are no significant graphical upgrade from the last gen version except for resolution bump. However the game is still pretty with the different locations. Where the PS5 version shines is the use of it’s features. Loading screen has almost gone. It take from 1 second or between 2 to 3 seconds to load depending on the location you are fast travelling to. Very impressive. I never thought I would say that but I miss the tips from loading screen of the PS4 version with the beautiful art style. My most anticipated featured was the Dualsense implementation. You get a feedback from almost everything from the game: menu screen, cutscenes, rolling, riding on wood bridge or rock from your horse, sword clashing and even when playing the flute. Did it surpass Astro Playroom? I don’t know but its very good. It will be hard to go to PS4 version to collect remaining trophies of Iki Island. The Director’s Cut comes with the above mentioned expansion and it does not disappoint. Like the main game, the new island has beautiful location to explore. My favorite is simply scaling the white marble like cliff. Iki introduce new activities to do outside the main quest like the Archer mastery challenge that will test your skills or the animal sanctuary that will provide with new charms that will change your play style. Speaking of which, two new mythic tales to get awesome rewards from both. The first one is horse armor to charge towards your enemies. I truly believe this feature was missing from the main game. The second one will get you a new armor for Jin that make gameplay comes with risk reward situation. Least to say its my new favorite armor. I started a NG+ to play with it. Since the PS5 version dropped, I have noticed some drop in quality of matchmaking in Legends mode. In average it takes longer to have a match. In average between 1m30 to 3m. Also during a match, if a player has left a session and you select “ search other player for matchmaking” to bring a new player during the session, it never works. It keep searching but no one comes in. This happened in 100% matches that a player has left. Sucker Punch will need to add an option to turn off adaptive trigger for hunter class only. ( I don’t want to use the general one as I love it in the main campaign )   Overall I 100% recommend GOT DC for any new player.

As a lifelong fan of Sucker Punch, I took a full month to play through their newest masterpiece, Ghost of Tsushima. Much like Naughty Dog had progression from platforming with Crash Bandicoot, to Jak & Daxter, and arriving to large storytelling with Uncharted & The Last of Us, Sucker Punch has done the same. Sly Cooper served as their foundation, Infamous was honest fun, and now Ghost of Tsushima surpasses them both and pushes them to that same level of masterful storytelling. Ghost of Tsushima is an absolute beauty. The gorgeous environments are so breathtaking I could spend another month just riding around the beautiful island of Tsushima, seeing falling leaves, crashing waves, and adorable foxes. Being put in the shoes of a lovable main character in Jin adds another level of joy as he struggles with the concept of right and wrong based from how he was raised versus how the pain of war unfolds. Along the way you meet many characters with their own side quest lines, and honestly they were equally as enjoyable as the main story. The combat in this game was also perfection; Sucker Punch clearly learned a lot from both Sly Cooper and Infamous and put them both to work here, mixing elements of hack and slash with stealth and techniques, this game truly was perfection from beginning to end. It's also very generous with checkpoints and giving you a bit of health if you keep dying at any portions. If I have any complaint at all about this game, it's only a minor gripe about some of the side-quests and some of the main narrative. This is not a happy game; it has beautiful moments and things that make you smile, but this is war and war is not pretty, and sometimes the side-quests reflect this by being terribly depressing with no good feels to walk away with, and I do prefer a bit of balance. But that really is a tiny drop in the a large beautiful ocean that is Ghost of Tsushima.

More new content and a whole stunning island to explore. This is DLC done right. And the upgrade to ps5 specs makes the game even more beautiful. You will not regret buying this game. See my previous review below: Ghost of Tsushima is a stunning game. I have never before played a game with such a vibrant open world. It feels lived-in, it feels living. Before GoT I never experienced ASMR from a video game. Now I do. The falling of leaves, petals etc make this a magical world akin to something from a Studio Ghibli film. Equal parts Journey, Bushido Blade and Tenchu this is a game that has been constructed to please the people who forked out for it. Comparing it to TLOU2 is unfair to Naughty Dog because GoT blows it away. I dont know why anyone would choose TLOU2's edgelord nihilism over the magic of GoT - a game whose creators went out of their way to make enjoyable. Also comparisons to Assassins Creed persist but speaking as a fan of AC since the first one (though not so much recently) I am not throwing the games under the bus when I say that AC has never been this good. Not even close. Jin Sakai is a great MC who veers away from the preaching that has become commonplace in Western games and proves that gamers do not need forced MCs who mirror them at the threat of twitter mob outrage. There could be a case made that it is not as long as some other open world games but I would counter that there is no extraneous flab in GoT. Just classy, relevant substance. Its side missions serve a purpose, add to the plot and build the world Jin is trying to save. The add fuel to Jin's desire to save it at all costs. It is so refreshing to have side missions that serve a purpose and aren't just 'Deliver this persons frying pan'. It is a game that makes you care about its casts philosophies without badgering you with encyclopedias on why you're supposed to care (a la Death Stranding). Its world is magical and you want to protect it as much as Jin does. It isnt an exercise in making you feel like crap like TLOU2. It captures the essence of nature and play (which in reality are intertwined anyway). Ghost of Tsushima is a strong contender for Game of the Year and it would take something godlike to deny it.

GHOST OF TSUSHIMA REVIEW I gave Ghost of Tsushima a solid 10/10, so I will not explain the base game, I will focus on the new aspects and the brand-new island of Iki SETTINGNews gets to Jin that the island of Iki is being invaded by a new Mongol ruler, the Eagle, so he departs there to stop the Mongol invasion there to avert once and for all the Mongol threat.Whilst traveling to Iki, Jin’s boat collapses in a storm and he is left stranded. Then he awakes in Iki and the story unfolds MECHANICSSimilar as with the base game, but I will add a few additional mechanics •	Exploration:Now there are animal shrine whew you use your flute to control via motion controls the rhythm of the melody, so the animal can be attracted to you. You will be rewarded with charms or enhancements to specific charms.I would have loved the option of enhancing what I want, but either way getting to these shrines is amazing.There is also know archery challenges, which are very nice and some of them are tricky. If you manage to beat them fast enough you will also be rewarded. Add the haptic feature of the PS5 controllers and you will feel a bow in your hand!Finally, you get to fight in an arena with a wooden sword. This was also cool, and the battles are directed to just one hit, to start a new round.The island of Iki is short in area compared to Tsushima (about ¼) but that does not mean exploration is easy. There is a lot of vertical areas which have difficult accesses. Exploration is still a nice addition to the perfect combat! •	Combat:Oh boy, they got it right... Mud, blood, Sweat, and Steel! and well said, as I have never played such an addictive combat gampleya which hooked me in so much... this was the beginning of my original GoT review… I stand for it in the Director’s cut as now combat has been revamped with nice additions such as a lock on feature. The Shamans will enhance enemies and they will become more aggressive, meaning they will get you with unblockable attacks repeatedly. Adding to that, now there are enemies that can change weapons during battle, and you will be changing stances even more now. Overall, combat is more challenging now.Finally, there is a new skill to charge enemies with your horse! It is a satisfying addition to add an additional tactical level to the already challenging and awesome combat •	StealthSame good stealth mode with improved assassination animations. No major changes in here, really. Stealth was good in the original, it has improved in this one with cooler animations VISUALSVisuals were great and now they have been overhauled a little more. Do not expect a major change in here as already the PS4 version was jaw dropping, but there is an improvement, and now for us lovers of Japanese Samurai cinema… there is sync lip for Japanese language. Doing this must have been really difficult as this is a RPG game and you talk with literally EVERYONE. SOUNDSoundtrack is amazing and epic, adding to an already incredible soundtrack not only for GoT but also for GoT Legends. What I love most about the soundtrack is how it adapts to the environment. FINAL VERDICTI give this game a solid 10/10. I bought the base PS4 version and I was ok to pay for the upgrade not only for the new expansion with Iki Island (which will take 10 to 15 hours to complete as a whole) but also for the revamp in the graphics, and audio. Go get it and become one of the most badass Shinobi!

So this is my review of the game, not a review of the company’s pricing decisions like all of these other reviews seem to be. Ghost of Tsushima is a tough one to review, because it has a lot of great qualities while still being relatively mundane. To me, it feels like this game is an Assassins Creed spin-off still made by Ubisoft. I found the game to be good, but not great.. The gameplay is extremely lackluster in the combat, it really feels like a refined and polished Assassins Creed game - which again isn’t a bad thing, but to be fully objective it’s not that complex. It gets a little better toward the last act in the game, but it’s fairly straight forward.  The stealth feels like the old Tenchu games, which is extremely basic, but the AI is absolutely atrocious in this game, which makes the stealth even more ridiculous. The game just gave me this unpolished feeling. The actual missions are mostly very much the same “clear this outpost” or “attack that group”, and they don’t really bring any excitement aside from moving the story forward a little bit. I very much enjoyed the story, however, It really feels that 90% of the game is filler. Act 1 is the longest act, and the storyline completely lost my attention until toward the end of Act 2. Once the story picks up, it tells a pretty good story.  The world is beautiful, although a bit empty since it’s mostly just landscapes - again it’s not a bad thing because the landscapes are stunning, but there’s not much happening and it feels very empty. The lighting and grass effects are absolutely beautiful, especially in 4K and 60fps. There are a few areas where the the textures look a bit muddy, for example, the water looks really really bad.. None of the issues are game breakers by any means, but they just add to the feeling that the game is unpolished, even on the PS5. The atmosphere is excellent, everything including the historical accuracy, the music, the voice acting, the story, it’s all fantastic. My final thoughts: the game is good, but it polishes up a formula that had existed and has been overdone for over a decade now. Ghost of Tsushima "Directors Cut" is clearly the most complete experience of Jin Sakai's journey. Overall the extra content really could be considered just a DLC for the game however the base game includes features that were unavailable in the original release. For instance the Directors Cut includes Japanese lip-sync which is 1:1 with the Japanese localization. Originally this wasn't available. As well features such as real-time Cinematics, target lock, along with repayable content in addition to the optimized version of the game for the PS5. For me personally the real value is the addition to Jin's back story which is peppered through Iki-Island. We learn more about Jin's Father as well as some new story elements about his Mother. I felt that the updated version of the game allowed for a more complete "Hero's Journey" of the game and allowed me to experience more of the Ghost and his world which is in my opinion a good thing.

If you like Ghost of Tsushima you will like Ghost of Tsushima Directors Cut because it’s just more of the same, with a new vibrant island, new enemies and new abilities. More of the same doesn’t mean bad because Ghost is an excellent game and the new content give you a reason to return to the game after completing the main game. While the story on Iki Island isn’t the greatest thing in the world, I do think if you liked the base game and want more, you should definitely buy the $20 upgrade.

SuckerPunch Productions took a great game and made it so much better with the Iki Island expansion, better Legends MP, better sound, use of SSD, use of 3D Audio. This game is one of the best-looking games ever!

I wasn’t happy about how the director’s cut charged me for the upgrade, but I am willing to pay the extra to support a masterpiece like this. The stunning scenery and the elegant combat make this game a must-play for every next-gen player. 60 FPS does make everything smoother, and I truly enjoyed my new game + playthrough.
